Project idea: While the next step for Truffle is to write authoring tools so more people can join in the fun, I'm considering giving Vue a second shot. Reflection: I drove to a park on Sunday and had one of these moments where I realize how the technology that's really worth it often takes the longest to mature. I got involved with podcasting back in late 2004, before iTunes even had a podcast directory. There were a handful of mostly experimental podcasts out there, many in the format of "sorry I haven't podcasted in a while, here's an episode; sorry about the audio quality." There was no iPhone yet, and the idea was that you would have a piece of software that would sync episodes to a playlist in your iPod. My contribution to the community was a content management system plugin that generated RSS feeds with the <enclosure> tags that make podcasts work (even today.) Fast forward to Sunday, and I'm listening to Deborah Jian Lee interview Kate Bowler. I'm hit with a sense of awe and gratitude. I have a device in my pocket that effortlessly connects to my husband's car stereo and automatically plays interviews like this one. Podcasting has grown to the point that I now have to be selective about which ones I'm subscribed to! I no longer maintain the plugin I wrote (nor do I any longer use that CMS), but I know that for many years, it helped keep the community going. The software engineer in me wishes all of the software we write could be reusable, but the planner in me sees that all code is ultimately temporary. No code is truly wasted, if it contributes to a long term goal! All food for thought as I work on Truffle: my personal software project.

Today is Trans Day of Visibility. I‚Äôm not transgender and honestly I was quite ignorant of the experiences of trans/non-binary people until more recent years. I was introduced to a handout called ‚Äúthe genderbread man‚Äù (Google it, there‚Äôs a PDF), which helped my understanding quite a bit. But the most important thing I‚Äôve learned is that we need to listen. There are a lot of gender identities and experiences that are grouped under the trans* umbrella, and it‚Äôs better to listen than assume. I know I haven‚Äôt always been the best at that, but I‚Äôm still learning and trying.
Been making this for small group dinner with my church. As always, these are rough estimates on portions, scale to taste. I might try adding chili paste in with the meat next time.
Ingredients: 2 lbs ground beef (grass fed makes a difference here)
1 T peanut oil (or other high temp oil)
1/3 cup of hoisin based marinade (I've been using Soy Vay)
Recipe: Start steaming your rice on before you start on the rest of the meal, especially if you're cooking brown rice. Peel and chop about a thumb's worth of ginger, then fry it in a large skillet with the oil. After 30-60 seconds, add the ground beef. Cook the beef until none of it is still visibly pink. At this point, drain the fat from the beef. Add the marinade to the beef and continue cooking on medium heat for 5 minutes, sirring constantly so it doesn't scortch. Meanwhile (or beforehand), prepare the fresh vegetables. Peel carrots and chop off the ends. Then using a veggie peeler or mandolin, peel long, thin strips of carrot. Peel, seed, quarter, and chop the cucumber into no thicker than 1/4 inch pieces. Rinse the cliantro (make sure you don't have any sand or dirt), chop off the ends before you get to the leaves, then break the rest of the stalks into thirds. Set out bowls: allow diners to fill a bottom layer of rice, followed by the beef, and then topped with the fresh vegetables. Also set out any condiments desired (e.g., sriracha, kimchi, chili sauce, etc...) Serves 6-8.

Career advice: Give new frameworks at least a year (ideally two), before investing serious time into using them. When you're working with pre-v1.0 projects, anti-patterns abound!

Reflection: Spent almost a full decade working with an open-source CMS and a community of interesting people. It was my profession, my hobby, and (if I'm being honest) my friends all rolled into one big ball. I got to a point where I realized I was spending more time bringing new technology into the context of that CMS than I was learning how to be a better software developer. I had to move away from being an "expert" in that world and start over with something new. Some of my skills did transfer, but I also had to come to terms with "dropping stuff on the floor" and not picking it up again.

Read this yesterday. For much of my upbringing, a lot of focus was put on 'the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms' in the form of spiritual warfare. But if you take a closer look at the list in verse 12, it starts off by first listing 'rulers' and 'authorities' as our adversaries, while still maintaining that 'our struggle is not against flesh and blood.' What does this passage look like when we read it being about institutions and governments rather than more abstract forces?

I've said it before, but I'll say it again: don't make New Year's Resolutions in January. You're still either hungover or coming off a sugar high! Spend the month of January thinking of some things you want to accomplish this year, then coming up with some achieveable milestones towards that goal. Then put your plan into place on Chinese New Year. You gain six weeks of planning!

He‚Äôs gone on takeout runs, been understanding when I wanted to ring in the new year with cough syrup instead of champagne, reminded me that we have sudafed, and did my grocery shopping on a Sunday afternoon at HEB üèÜ. 2018 is going to be great! Over the past couple of years, I've been learning about the Enneagram personality typing system. I like it over other systems for a few reasons. One reason is that it works more like a spectrum of personality: everyone's unique, but you tend to have one set of personality traits that are stronger than the others. Another reason is that the Enneagram shows how each personality picks up characteristics of another personality as they move towards health or stress. My Enneagram type is 1, also known as the Reformer or the Perfectionist. As I become more emotionally healthy, I move towards type 7 (the Enthusiast.) I'm finding that for me, the gateway towards 7 can come in the form of silliness! So I'm looking for more opportunities to practice silliness. Here's a photo of my green poop Christmas tree emoji hat.
Could we have sponsored driverless car rides?
"I just stopped listening to them." I think any small town would be lucky to have someone like Erica Leonard managing their mall!

A couple of stories that have held my attention this year: the "retail apocalypse" and driverless cars. While they're both happening now to varying extents, they're also several years away from being mainstream. If the peak of both hit at the same time, we'll have a situation where there will be acres of under/unused commercial space, surrounded by extraneous parking lots (especially if driverless cars are used exclusively for Uber/Lyft-style services.) On one hand, this could create a situation where people just move farther away from cities and suburbs to avoid living near dead malls. On the other hand, a lot of those parking lots could become new housing and office space. It'll be interesting to see how all of this pans out.

I'm willing to buy and sell things using Bitcoin, but I'm not willing to spend any dollars to buy them. How then would I get them? I've toyed around with the idea of having a Bitcoin-only garage sale or some sort of hobby business. I'm just not willing to go back and forth between USD and Bitcoin if the main point of Bitcoin is that centralized currencies are obsolete!
It's been unseasonably wet and warm today. Just when you thought it was 100% soup weather, you get hit with a warm snap.

If I'm being honest, this is my least favorite time of year. Not because of Christmas itself, but because there's this rush at the end of the year to accomplish things. Expectations and obligations pile up, and it wears on me. Whenever I try to express this to other people, I get a lot of unhelpful advice like "it's okay to be sad." The thing is, I'm not necessarily sad about anything. I feel like my body naturally wants me to slow down, while other people are trying to speed things up. It's exhausting. My coping strategy is pretty much just "grin and bear it."
We had a gift exchange this evening and I stole a peach candle. I love scented candles that much.

Ingredients: 1 T overly reduced apple cider (syrup consistency)
Recipe: While the water boils, put the overly reduced cider in a mug. Slice a small piece of fresh ginger and add it to the mug. Once the water boils, pour the water over the ginger and cider syrup. Stir and sip.

Comment: Trying to find a way of centrally accepting Truffle data, while writing minimal backend code. Don't want to write something that I have to invest time in keeping up.
I'm now distributing Truffles without camel-cased field names, let's see how this works!

Today I am debating about the suggestion that `id` fields in Truffle be UUIDs. If at all possible, I would love to change this to a human-readable value. We could keep the idea that computers will generating the value for us automatically, but it would be nice if we could keep with the idea that all Truffle data should be human readable.
Two things: first, today I realized you can use almost any string for JSON keys except for a single digit. Second, I may be renaming Truffle to something more descriptive. Stay tuned!

I've been running into an issue with rendering truffles, and I think I've discovered the root: since I'm rendering things without knowing what properties will be available, frameworks like Vue and React cannot predict what I'm going to give them, which really makes the code difficult to write (not to mention causes performance issues.) What I need to do to remedy this is parse the truffle properties into an array of objects so they can be a bit more predictable.
Been enjoying the posts from this Instagram account. It takes Purity Culture books (e.g. books telling you to court instead of date) and blacks out all but a few words to create a bit of art.

Battling yet another bout of "writer's block" with Truffle. I want this to be something I can truly share with people; something that has use beyond my own amusement and exploration. I want it to be something people can use to make the Internet a more hospitable place. I want it to be fun. But it's still lingering here in this this zone between something I do exclusively for my own entertainment and something other people can run with. It's like every time I come up with an idea of how to make it easy, I dig in and discover it either will take far more time than have or that it will still be too complicated and limited. I know this will progress at some point, it just might not be right now.

Tagging is a feature I just sort of decided to add to Truffle on a whim. You tag a truffle by setting a property to `true`. The only thing is that in JavaScript, the widely held convention is to reserve the use of capitalized names for object constructor functions and classes. I've realized this isn't a hard and fast rule. Therefore, in Truffle it's possible to declare a tag with a first capital letter. (Or so we will see when this parses.) You can then continue the rest of the tag in CamelCase, the way you would with a hashtag.

Did most of my Thanksgiving shopping today. Also reflecting on my first Thanksgiving with Andrew. It was my first time hosting Thanksgiving and I was super-excited! Had all of my ingredients ready to go and we had a guest from out of town. Andrew had to work that day, but we made time to have breakfast together. His family has a tradition of eating cinnamon rolls, so he put some in the oven. He told me to check on them; when I did, they were raw and cold. My oven was dead. I started panicking. One of his coworkers texted "let me know if you need anything" to which he replied "do you have a kitchen we can borrow?" She did! As Andrew went to work, I packed all of our groceries in the car, drove over to his coworker's apartment, and made Thanksgiving dinner. I'll always be thankful for her generosity that day in letting a bunch of meat-eaters cook in her vegetarian kitchen!

Today is a day where I'm remembering to practice joy. Today was crappy. Whether it's allerges, seasonal affective disorder, frustrations, disappointments, or even loss, it all seems to have hit myself and everyone around me today. Joy isn't about taking bitter situations and drowing them in sugar syrup so they average out to saccharine. As I've learned, real joy is about not letting your circumstances overcome your gifts and calling. It allows you to say, "yeah, this sucks, but it doesn't change who I am and why I'm here."

Looked up a few beef stew recipes for the Instant Pot and ended up making my own.
Recipe: Making some beef stew in the Instant Pot. Coated the beef cubes in about a quarter cup of flour (shook them in a take out container), then let them brown in the pot on the Saute setting. When the meat was brown to my liking, I poured in the beer, then scraped up the bits on the bottom with a spatula. Put in all of the other ingredients (chopped ahead of time), put the lid on, set the function to Stew and the time to 35 minutes.

Having a moment of frustration with a bug that makes absolutely no sense. It's moments like these where I really want to quit and feel guilty for spending time on a project like this to begin with. But what I usually find helps best is to put the problem down for the moment, take a breath, address something else, and then come back later. Usually, I can code around what I was originally getting blocked by, or the solution just becomes obvious after spending some time away from it.

I took this recipe from Tasty Ever After and simplified it a bit. Received many compliments!
Recipe: Peel and chop the onion and garlic. Place both in the Instant Pot with your olive oil and turn on the Saute function. Saute the onion and garlic until soft. Add all of the chicken, 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce, and all of the apple cider vinegar. Lock the lid, select the Poultry setting, and set the timer for 20 minutes. When the cycle is done, do a quick release, open the lid, and shred the chicken. There will be a lot of liquid at this point, do not worry. Leave the lid off and turn on the Saute function. Add the remaining 1/2 cup of barbecue sauce and mix for a few minutes as the chicken continues to thread. Spoon chicken onto medium sized, toasted buns. Serves 8.

I've sometimes said the thing that gets you hooked on programming is the moment you start getting more work out of a piece of code than what you put into it. However, a thought occurred to me today: instead of talking about the work I'm getting out of the code, what if I talked about the joy I'm getting out of it? The Truffle project is something I do in my spare time for no money. I don't believe I'll ever get rich off it, but there's certainly a lot of opportunity for joy. Part of what brings me joy is running the script that generates a "blank" truffle I can start filling. I'm making a point to start every session I work on Truffle with that joy!

Ingredients: Three medium carrots, chopped into rounds
Half of a bunch of kale, chopped (three stalks)
Recipe: Place the carrots, onions, kale, tomato sauce, and a few shakes of Italian seaoning in the pot. Add olive oil to a skillet and turn the heat to high. Fry up the garlic and fennel seed in the skillet for about 30 seconds. Brown the turkey in the skillet until it's cooked through. Close the pot and set it to high pressure for 10 minutes. Do a quick release and serve.

Today I played a little Instant Pot routlette. Here's what I made.
Ingredients: Half of a rotisserie chicken, deboned and defatted
Approximately 3 cups of chopped napa cabbage
Half a cup of red onion
Approximately a tablespoon of fish sauce
Approximately a tablespoon of soy sauce
Half a cup of plain water
Recipe: Peel and slice the sweet potatoes. Peel and mince the ginger. Chop the cabbage into bite-size strips. Place all of the ingredients in the Instant Pot for 10 minutes on high pressure, then use the quick release. Serve.

Comment: This one never gets old!
